content.text:
# Draft:Mayoral elections in Worcester, Massachusetts in the 19th century

1848
In 1848 (the year Worcester was granted a city charter), Worcester held its inaugural mayoral election. Levi Lincoln Jr. was elected mayor, defeating Rodney Miller (a local temperance advocate around whom opposition to the town's elites coalesced).  Lincoln won the election with a victory margin in excess of 10%.
1849
In 1849, Henry Chapin was elected mayor.
1850
In 1850, Henry Chapin was re-elected mayor.
1851
In 1851, Peter C. Bacon was elected mayor, winning by a margin of 668 votes.
Incumbent mayor Henry Chapin declined re-nomination.
1852
In 1852, John S.C. Knowlton was elected mayor.
1853
In 1853, John S.C. Knowlton was re-elected mayor, defeating Alexander Bullock.
1854
In December 1854, George W. Richardson was elected mayor of Worcester. Richardson, at the time the sheriff of Worcester County, had run as the nominee of the Know Nothings, and won with a margin-of-victory of 1,311. Richardson received a majority of 1,311 votes.
1855
In December 1855, Isaac Davis was elected mayor of Worcester.
1856
In December 1856, former mayor George W. Richardson was returned to office for a second non-consecutive term, securing a margin-of-victory of 55 votes.
1857
In December 1857, Isaac Davis was elected to a second non-consecutive term as mayor.
1858
In December 1858, Alexander Bullock was elected mayor of Worcester, narrowly defeating Republican nominee William W. Rice.
1859
In December 1859, Republican nominee William W. Rice was elected mayor of Worcester.
1860
In December 1860, Isaac Davis was returned to the mayoralty for a third non-consecutive term.
1861
In December 1861, Peleg Emory Aldrich was elected mayor of Worcester
1862
In 1862, Daniel Waldo Lincoln was elected mayor of Worcester.
1863
In December 1863, Daniel Waldo Lincoln was re-elected to a second term as mayor of Worcester.
1864
In December 1864, Phinehas Ball was elected mayor of Worcester.
1865
In December 1865, Republican nominee James B. Blake was elected mayor of Worcester, defeating Democratic nominee D. Waldo Lincoln.
1866
In December 1866, incumbent Worcester Mayor James B. Blake (a Republican) was re-elected to a second term, facing only a scattering of votes against him.
1867
In December 1867, incumbent Worcester Mayor James B. Blake (a Republican) was re-elected to a third term, defeating Democratic nominee Isaac Davis
1868
In December 1868, incumbent Worcester Mayor James B. Blake (a Republican) was re-elected to a fourth term, facing only a scattering of votes against him.
1869
In December 1869, incumbent Worcester Mayor James B. Blake (a Republican) was re-elected to a fifth term, defeating Democratic nominee J. Henry Hill.
1870
In December 1870, incumbent Worcester Mayor James B. Blake (a Republican) was re-elected to a sixth term, defeating Democratic nominee J. Henry Hill. However, Blake died days after the election, and former mayor Henry Chapin was appointed to fill the mayoralty ad interim.
1871 (special election)
In early 1871, Edward Earle won election to fill the remainder of an unexpired mayoral term in a special election. James B. Blake had died in December 1870, shortly after winning election to a sixth term, triggering the special election.
1871 (regular election)
In December 1871, George F. Verry was elected mayor of Worcester.
1872
In December 1872, Clark Jillson was elected mayor of Worcester.
1873
1874
1875
1876
1877
1878
1879
1880
1881
1882
1883
1884
1885
1886
1887
1888
1889
In December 1889, Republican nominee Francis Alfred Harrington was elected mayor, defeating A. George Bullock (the nominee on both the Citizen and Democratic tickets).
1890
In December 1890, incumbent mayor Francis Alfred Harrington (a Republican) was re-elected, defeating Benjamin W. Childs.
1891
In December 1891, incumbent mayor Francis Alfred Harrington (a Republican) was re-elected, defeating Joseph S. Perry.
1892
1893
1894
1895
1896
1897
In December 1897, Republican nominee Rufus B. Dodge was elected mayor of Worcester.
James Logan had been considered a very likely Republican nominee, but opted not to run.
1898
In December 1898, Republican incumbent Rufus B. Dodge was re-elected mayor of Worcester.
1899
In December 1899, Republican incumbent Rufus B. Dodge was re-elected to a third term as mayor of Worcester.
1900
In 1900,
